text: -- of Section 305 of the Postal Service and Public Employees Salary Act of 1962.
Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.
Mr. General, so you admit that the National Security felt that --
The matter was reviewed by the National Security of Council and it concluded that the statute serves no useful purpose.
So that was an amendment to what?
To the pay-raise bill.
Which one?
The one that we all finally got Your Honor.
Oh.
I do not make excuse of it Your Honor.
What did you say, that was all authored by?
The ori -- the -- it stemmed from a bill originally offered by Senator Butler of Maryland, I think.
Thank you.
Ultimately there -- went through the Congress.
But if a speech reprinted in the Time were put in a letter form in Russia and sent here that would be “communist propaganda”, isn't it?
If it were printed in pamphlets form so that it's not sealed.
Although it appeared in the New York Times.
That would be treated as "communist political propagandas".
How will the man know --
How will the man know whether he's on the list that the Postmaster General thinks he ought to look at this mail?
I don't suppose he would.
I am talking about -- I'm talking abut this mail.
Well, you're talking about the mail that as --
(Voice Overlap)
The man I described as bookseller sends this out.
Mail that's sent to him like I get all the time that I never ask for, some of it are never wanted.
No.
Yes, but --
I was saying that the Postmaster General or has on occasion made spot checks of the matter deposited in the mails by such a person to see whether he was obliged to provide Section 305 to it.

Well, does that mean, for example if John Jones had addressed to him a box of a thousand pamphlets with a communist manifesto from Moscow, it might be that the Post Office would see how many of those he dropped in the mail, is that it?
It might be that the Customs Bureau would discover that John Jones was getting a great deal of this.
Yes.
And it might then say to the Post Office, “John Jones is getting a great deal of foreign communist propaganda, you would better see whether Section 305 applies to it”.
Apply it to what he is mailing.
Might look at what he is mailing --
Yes.
-- and then apply the steps of the statute.
Yes.
His mail would -- what he deposits would go into the mail.
Are you going to tell us why?
Because I think that the foreign -- well, I have to face up the question of the rights of the recipients.
Well, any --
So I say, I have to face the problem with the rights of the recipients and I intend to do it.

But what I meant was you're going to say why that this same kind of law couldn't be constitutionally applied to people in this country who want to send this same politic -- “communist propaganda” inside the country.
Oh!
And the other --
When he is abroad.
Do I understand yet on his mail on behalf of the Hanoi Government from South Vietnam, it's not screened?
At the present time the South Vietnam may not be --
It's being screened.
-- screened.
May it please the Court.
May it please the Court.
